commentBody: Nice stack in the middle.  It looked harder than it ended up.  Top was a little tough, worked my way thru once and then went bottom up.
"Bajo" means "low" and "alto" means "high", so it is correct to consider them opposites.
Decent puzzle.
Finished in 8:05 - wasn't particularly difficult but I enjoyed it.

Waiting for the thunderous applause
from all the posters who hate rebuses
and themes and tricks and proper nouns
and just want a plain old crossword.

(I'm not going to say 
it means a lot to me.)




Nice one, Adrian.
The clue for set is an interesting way of defining the word, which by the way has the most pages devoted to it of any word in the oed I believe

Very rapid Friday for me which means nothing more than that the constructor and I were on the same wavelength for once.  2D Booster, perhaps I tried SEAT and SHOT and both led nowhere so I had to erase them. And I did have Emily's list confused with Angie's list for far too long.  Shame on me.
Easy breezy Friday.

So frustrating!! At first it looked challenging (so much white space) but I was able to breeze throught it and was well on my way to getting a PB... but for some reason, I just could not find my error.... turns out I had misspelled EtHEMERAL. In my defense, I had never heard of PUCE nor TUCE before now, so the cross didnt help much.
It was nice to have a puzzle without gimmicks.
Wasn't thrilled with the EPHEMERAL/PUCE and SENT/SKABANDS crossings, but good puzzle otherwise

Before attempting 3D, ask your doctor if it‚Äôs right for you.




cc: emu handler
Really fun puzzle with lots of cleverly constructed clues

A really easy puzzle‚Äîafter it was solved.  Along the way, there was so much interplay of all kinds of clues, which looked impossible until the fills sort of strutted across the grid or slid down in unexpected ways.  It all added up to a memorable Friday of pure enjoyment.  

Thank you, Adrian Johnson.  Did I say I loved it?

My whole life I thought PUCE was a shade of green. Confusing it with puke green, no doubt, so TI finally L. 
It's also a good thing I looked up the meaning of pupusa, me thinking that it was related to a stage of insect life.
On the other hand, PORTRAIT ARTISTS and SKA BANDS went right into their slots. 
Chicken or mashed potato DANCE made me laugh.

An easygoing Friday puzzle.
Breezy and fun. Missed my Friday record by just under a minute. Thanks!

Took me too long to think of "toque" as a French word, especially with zero other context that the clue required a French response. Possibly because it is a specialized term with no one-word English equivalent. 

"Spot for a chapeau" would have conveyed the intent more clearly.

This was a great puzzle, to the UMPTEENTH degree.

My one big "qvorsk" (Deb, please copyright that!) was having put in STuNK instead of STANK, leaving me with the senseless IT_EANSULO_T___. 
I stared and stared at this qvorsk until the penny dropped, and I changed that "u" to "a."

The rest was a perfect balance of smooth as silk, but still needing a thinking cap.  

I've got nothing but love for this puzzle.
Thank you, Mr. Johnson!

Dear Ms. Amlen:

Bajo is Spanish for ‚Äúlow.‚Äù Alto is Spanish for ‚Äúhigh‚Äù

That is how they are opposites.  The opposite of a bass would be soprano. 

Oddly enough tubas and piccolos are the loudest instruments due to their depths and heights of sound.
TIL that female llamas respond very much like the female humans I used to ask out in high school.

Started with bigBANDS for 5A. [horns] (saxophones to us) are almost a defining feature of them. 
A rather sneaky misdirection.

I loved this!  It was a just-right Friday for me.  I had to poke around to get some footing and the bottom ended up going super smooth.  I had a blast working my way back up wrapping up the intersections of UMPTEENTH, PEACEDEAL and INTHEZONE.  I had initially put Eddie Griffin instead of Kathy early on which threw me off a bit lol. 

A wonderful ode to Donia!
Confusingly Juno also keeps coming up as the Roman goddess of childbirth though of course it does not fit here.

I prefer a Friday puzzle that is too hard to just fill in, unlike this  one. I started at top left and sailed through.Feeling frustrated and almost at a loss and then managing to finish correctly is somehow more satisfying and reassuring.

The car salesman told me where to find his dealership. It meant a lot.

(Posting this pun was auto-matic.)

Note to self:

Fridays and Saturdays require full focus. Other days can be fun to do while watching a game, or a show, (or a game show), but you can‚Äôt play around with a Friday. Gotta be IN THE ZONE.

I thought this puzzle was going to be another killer, while I was watching the NFL opener with one eye, but it turned out to be a perfect Friday once I switched off and tuned in. Still tough (for me), but manageable.

Thanks, Adrian Johnson!

If I walk less than 10 minutes in 3 different directions from my home, I can buy a pupusa from an El Salvador native, an arepa made by a woman from Panama and an empanada from an Argentinian family.
Each operates from a food kiosk and only sells their specialty plus soda. Each kiosk is in a parking lot adjacent to a liquor store.  (The proximity of 3 liquor stores is not the reason I bought my house)

I overall enjoyed this one quite a bit. It was somewhat tricky but, I still came in well under my average. I ended up looking up the Proverbs verse, though in retrospect, I should have been able to guess ANT from the ‚Äúthou sluggard; consider her ways‚Äù part of the clue and already having A_T from crosses. I kept thinking that I must have had something wrong in that area because I had never heard the term T-MEN before and was somewhat surprised when the puzzle complete chime played after entering that ‚ÄòN.‚Äô I guess I‚Äôd never considered exactly how Eliot Ness‚Äôs org chart looked, but I suppose Treasury makes perfect sense if you recall that the Bureau of ùòàùò≠ùò§ùò∞ùò©ùò∞ùò≠, Tobacco and Firearms was part of that department until 2003. Dagnabbit, George W. Bush! Rendering this puzzle harder to complete was clearly the worst thing you did as president!

Easy puzzle.  So let us discuss getting an option to turn off statistics as a preference. Not enjoying seeing it added to Connections. Don't care about streaks, I have a life and sometimes miss days and it can be annoying to feel like the site is criticizing me for it.  I'm sure many love the statistics but an option to turn them off would be nice.

I quite liked this puzzle, even though I had to look up several trivia clues (Emily's List was a huge mystery to me, but now I looked it up and will gladly remember it) and unknown words (e.g. peke which I ask about below). I was stumped by the NE corner, but I asked my wife for help and together we dealt with it quickly.

Is peke a pekingese? I am always amazed by how common it is in English, and especially American English, to shorten words. Of course we sometimes do it in Polish, too, but much, much more rarely. A pekingese is always just... a pekingese (peki≈Ñczyk).

3 female names (4 if you count EDEN) in the SE corner is crazy work, was really fun to work out though thanks to the clever clueing. Now i'd like to see a puzzle that is able to fit all the names in mambo no.5, that would be fun!

The first pass through the 'across' clues netted me only END and SAAB and I knew this would be trouble. But a few breakthroughs later and it began to fall into place. Cracked 39A by some miracle and then I was on a roll. Super fun, challenging and satisfying puzzle.
the explanation given for 35D is making me giggle. it has nothing to do with music! [Bajo's opposite] is ALTO because bajo in Spanish means low and alto means high...

I just wanna call BS on yesterday‚Äôs Letter Boxed!

It is at turns, the most infuriating and satisfying puzzle in the lineup.  

I had ENJOYMENTs‚Ä¶.  quickly for once.

And I searched, and I searched, to no avail.

Poor me.  And anyone else searching for TEXTSPEAK.

Aaaaarrrrrrgggghhh.  :(

I must have been IN THE ZONE. Answers just kept coming to me.  

Hopefully, no RAW NERVES were hit, and everyone will be happy today.

Now I'll grab some SKA albums that I have ON CD, get in my car,  pop one in the drive, and go.

Here's an encore Adrian‚Äôs heart-warming and wise constructor‚Äôs notes from January of last year, which are so worth repeating:


‚ÄúThe day I received the review proof of this puzzle was also the day my grandfather died.

‚ÄúNormally I‚Äôd have a profound puzzle insight to share, but what‚Äôs on my mind today is gratitude ‚Äî for the time I spent with him, but particularly for the friendship Alvin, a dear family friend, forged with him during his final years.

‚ÄúAlvin, who began as his landscaper, first came by as a casual friend after grandpa‚Äôs hip replacement, continuing to come over regularly during the 11 years that grandpa outlived my grandma. Alvin‚Äôs visits often took the shape of coffee and conversation after dropping his kids off at school. They discussed things including family, life, hobbies and current events. Some days grandpa would invite Alvin for steak dinners, but other days they‚Äôd barely speak and spend the morning watching the news.

‚ÄúThe important thing was his presence: the conscious, routine decision to be involved and engaged, and to make the mundane life of an old man meaningful. Tonight, this morning, whenever you‚Äôre reading this, take a few minutes to say hello and check in with someone older whom you care about. Those hellos can make all the difference.‚Äù
So close to getting my first Friday without hints. It's driving me crazy. Everything filled, but an error somewhere. Probably in the answer for pupusa relative. No idea what that is. I'll keep at it.

Oh BABY!!

Felt un-crackable.
No *way* am I gonna get through this one.

Then‚Ä¶one falls in, then another.
Center opened up! 
Whaaa?

And then, one by one
NE, SE..they all just became clear!
NW was last to fall, but by then,
I was crucivibing. 

Felt like dancing!

Friday bliss.

POY candidate! 

Happy Friday all!
Fun puzzle. Particularly like YARDSALE and DANCE. Clever.
This was a fun one!  It made more sense once I realized 7D was not "Frankenfurter's cry"  Rocky Horror anyone?
Fun, a bit too easy for a Friday, but I‚Äôll take it!

I was very concerned about what those female llamas might be doing for a few minutes.



I wonder if Emus do it too?

Egads! ko is SPITting at me.

Thank you Adrian.  This one was fun and we got the gold.

I lost four minutes of time staring trying to find what was keeping me from the solve‚Ä¶
YAP/YIP and APROMISE/IPROMISE was frustrating.
Really fun. Definitely on the easy side for a Friday but that‚Äôs not a bad thing at all. SKABANDS made me laugh.

Phew! Some of those clues (like 5A) were absolutely diabolical!

I don't know how so many people found this easy. I certainly didn't. 

I did enjoy it though, once I corrected all my wrong answers and was able to appreciate the clever misdirections. It was definitely a brain workout!
The pedant in me wants 25D to be ‚Äúindifference‚Äù or ‚Äúuninterestedness‚Äù to avoid the anrgument about what disinterest is.

Upper left was terrifying for a minute or three (only thing I had was the hyperbolic ordinal), but by the time I hit the upper right it started to come together and the whole thing turned out to be fairly quick.

A fair and interesting puzzle, just right for Friday.  The "stacks" are fine I guess but not in love with the phrases.  For a change I'm mostly in agreement with the Wordplay columnist (except where she claims lookups are ok).  ;)

I think my favorite clue was Battleship (for nostalgia, not cleverness).

____________________

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade

TIL what a booster club does. In my high school, the booster squad was loosely made up of students that tried to promote student participation in pep rallies as far as I knew. I don‚Äôt recall there being a booster club in my college.  You learn something new every day.

I so wanted the multiple  horns to be horns of a DILEMMA, which curiously  fit in the squares. Perhaps another tine.

Fun puzzle my best time  for a friday in a while. Good Job
What exactly is a "stack"?

This one gave me a good workout! Filled in three fourths of the puzzle quite fast (for me), and then was stuck for a long time with the NE. Having never heard the word slider used to refer to a food item sort of stopped me cold. But eventually, I figured that out through just trying various combinations and then when 17A fell - I should have got this earlier, but somehow it took time - it all came together. This puzzle also had very few names and references that I have little chance of packing away in my subconscious given where I live, and so, I felt good I could solve this one with no lookups and sheer persistence! Yay.

Two clues made me laugh:
7D [Frankfurter‚Äôs cry] - My first thought was, ‚ÄúHow do you spell that?‚Äù thinking Adrian was asking for the sound it makes when you microwave it a bit too long! My German ancestors would say, ACH, Cherry!

11D [Chicken or mashed potato] DANCE? Of course! I have done the chicken dance at nearly every family wedding I‚Äôve been to! That‚Äôs one of my favorite clues of the year!

I had nth degree instead of UMPTEENTH at 18A, which threw me for quite a while. I was trying to put BIG PHARMA into 3D, but the H was in the wrong place... maddening.

Anyway, what with all this talk of chickens, mashed potatoes, AREPAs, and EMPANADAs, I am craving breakfast. So long!

An entertaining set of witty clues and unexpected answers.

The peace deal of not just cake *or* ice cream, but rather sum it (both), rings true. 

Am I just hungry, or was there an amazing amount of food in the puzzle today?

I looked right at SKABANDS multiple times, thinking to myself: "Well, that makes no sense... I must have an error somewhere in the crosses..." And following that by going over that whole section multiple times trying to catch the error that wasn't there.

I would not have completed this puzzle without some help from this peanut gallery; thank you. Limited time today, so I needed the boost. Yes, I could've waited and finished it tonight, but it's ER day and I know I'll just be too tired and want to do something mindless, like a jigsaw. 

Have fun folks! It's not so much that's difficult as that it requires some hard thinking. Hey, it's Friday. I stopped thinking on Wednesday. That's what happens when a rebus splits up my week!

Hmm...Kia ORA to you, Adrian.  How long ago di  you construct this??  

MONEY never sleeps.  Who knows about CITI's habits?  That ad must be from quite some time ago...maybe stored ON CD?

IN THE ZONE is not the same as "intensely focused," IMHO.  It denotes an altered state of consciousness; one finds s/he is "thinking with her hands"--as in creating a work of art.  It's actually a very restful place, while intense focus can be very tiring or draining.  

And I don't recall the presence of DIANA during L&D; maybe she went out of business during the Fall of the Roman Empire...

epi means ‚Äúupon‚Äù, ‚Äúon top of‚Äù
hemera means ‚Äúday‚Äù, ‚Äúthe day‚Äù

when epi is prefixed to a word beginning with ‚Äúh‚Äù (hard breathing), it elides to ‚Äúeph-‚Äú

So ephemeral literally means ‚Äúupon the day‚Äù / ‚Äúfor the day‚Äù. A day lily opens on a day, and closes forever after. It is ‚Äúepi-hemeral‚Äù: ephemeral.

If I don‚Äôt go for a walk when the cherries are in bloom,
I miss their beauty - because it is ephemeral.

ACH du lieber, big city stack. I do so appreciate the challenge of constructing one, but also of solving through one. Dipped a toe in with PMS and KOI, and was able to fill in from there. Nicely done, Adrian.

Hands up, who knew what a pangolin was before the Covid panic?

Haven‚Äôt had much spare time lately, but had to take a minute to compliment this puzzle. WOW ü§©, just WOW! And in doing so, I was lucky enough to read the constructor‚Äôs notes‚Äîlovely. The world definitely needs more Donias today‚Ä¶

Hope all is well with the Wordplay gang üòä.
I also had nthdegree before UMPTEENTH. Also "honed in on" before INTHEZONE. But it was a good Friday, less than average time, and I learnt BABU.  And now I'm craving chicken and mashed potatoes!

Hardly anything guessable without some crosses -- SKABANDS, PEACEDEAL, and the long spanners for example -- pretty typical for a Friday.  

Garden swimmer had me scratching my head for a while.  (Had to pool all my faculties to get than one)  

Finding BABY for mollycoddle took longer than expected, as did PIN.  

11D was a nice misdirect (was that chicken supposed to funky?).  

I am adding CITI to rust for those things that never sleep.  

TIL something about SODABREAD.  

Happy to finish in 25% less time than average.
Breezed through this one with just a couple of hiccups that I cleared up on my second pass. The only quibble I have is with 53D which seems a bit of a stretch, more of filler than anything else.
Nice puzzle. An actual crossword -- which is a bit of an anomaly in the NYT these days.

@Deb I believe 35D [Bajo's opposite] is referring to the Spanish meaning of bajo to be short and alto in Spanish meaning tall. I wish I could attach a screenshot of my Duolingo. I had to go back a few lessons to make sure I wasn't going crazy lol
Only square 28 remains blank, because I have no idea about either of them. Maybe it's just me, but seems unfair.
A thoroughly enjoyable crossword! Some gimmes, some tricky clues, some smart wordplay, and the triple 15-letter words through the middle - this is to me is what a Friday crossword should feel like.

Creating a good triple stack isn't easy, and they can be a bear to solve. I was surprised, therefore, that I got all three of the 15-letter strings in the stack almost immediately. It was a great confidence builder.

Nice puzzle today.
53 down should have been reclued. It still doesn‚Äôt really make sense to me.
I love late week puzzles like these when I'm on the same wavelength as the constructor and breeze through it. 11:28 today, 14 minutes below average.

Overall pretty easy puzzle for a Friday IMO, I think I would've found this somewhat easy even for a Thursday. NE took about the same amount of time to finish the bottom third of the puzzle but it wasn't too bad.

11D was a big fail, didn't get the connection until I had most of the crossers.
Bajo and alto are opposites in Spanish. They mean low and high respectively. I think that's what the puzzle creator was referring to.

If it's the name of a dance, shouldn't Mashed Potato be capitalized?  Not a big gripe, just a question.  I thought it was a great puzzle.  Got almost no answers on my first pass, but ended up solving it much quicker than my Friday average (though not a "Best") - funny when that happens!

Oooh... one more late puzzle find. A Sunday from January 26, 1986 by Bert Rosenfield with the title: "Doubled headers."

One 21 letter theme answer (paired with another answer):
DODOTHATVOODOTHATYOU*
Paired with: 
DOSOWELL*

Some other theme answers: 

MIRRORMIRROONTHEWALL* (also 21 letters)
OVEROVERTHERE*
GOINGGOINGGONE
REDREDROBIN*
NEVERNEVERLAND
MANYMANYMOONS*
NONONANETTE
TOOTOOSOLID

All of the asterisked answers above were making their one and only appearance in any puzzle. 

Thought that was a pretty clever idea. 

..

That was fun. A scary amount of white space at first that slowly filled. 
Alpacas, like llamas also SPIT. It‚Äôs the best test to see if the female is pregnant; taken to the ‚Äòoffending‚Äô male, she leaves him in no doubt that he did her wrong. My little herd are arriving next Spring, but they‚Äôre all girls so minimal spitting.

Got SKA BANDS straight away; as ska and punk have a lot of crossover music I was introduced in my teens at illicit Blues parties. Wild, but oh the beat.

27A a gimme of course, but oddly so was 1D. No idea where I dredged that up from.

A thoroughly enjoyable Friday after a couple of thoroughly enjoyable puzzles with fun tricks!  

This one seemed impossible. I had almost nothing on my first round. What I did have was kind of desperate stuff. Then, as I was staring at my grid thinking how I couldn't find a toe hold anywhere, EPHEMERAL simply leaped into my brain and I was off to the races! It's such a beautiful word!

Not to say it was so easy or too easy. The lower left and upper right corners were a bit tricky for me, with lots of things in and out, but all doable and in good (for me) time. My biggest hangup was entering NEONS at 11D at first, intending for it to go into 10D, of course. Whoops! 

Speaking ing of 11D, what fun!! Loved that one! One of my favorite young people in the world lives in Honduras, where we visit every year. Last time we were there, she was doing a tiktok dance at our house. My husband didn't know she was recording, nor did he know the dance or the music but he went over by her, scratched his head for a second, and started the chicken DANCE. It was hilarious and adorable! She didn't post it, but she sent it to me so I have video proof. All she could say about it was, "Cringy!" But she did laugh about it! It's fun to watch her go from the sweet, wanting to hang over all over us, little girl to full on preteen angst mode. She is a delight! As was this puzzle! 

Lots of fun and clever cluing and now I know how to ward off a male llama! Never know when that might come in handy, eh!?
Bajo / Baja mean low or lower, Alto / Alta mean high or upper. As in Baja California / Alta California, provinces of New Spain. Alta California is now known as California and Nevada.

A note to the constructor: 

I loved reading your notes celebrating your friend Donia! 

Just as you hope that we find the Donias in our lives, I hope that all the Donias out there find the Adrians in their lives, who so beautifully see, appreciate, and cherish them! 

Cheers to you both!
Great puzzle! So few fills on my first pass and then it slowly came together to be one of my best Fridays in awhile, time-wise.

A wonderful Friday puzzle. I love those phrases in the middle, and I think that was about where I first got a foothold. NE corner was my last spot to complete, probably because of [Frankfurter‚Äôs cry] and [Chicken or mashed potato]. Finally saw the light helped by PEACE DEAL, IN THE ZONE and FENCE.  I loved the clue for AREPA because it compared them to pupusas, a term I recently learned from my favorite book of the past year, Dave Eggers‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Eyes and the Impossible‚Äù. Pupusas are mentioned several times and I had to look them up, as I didn‚Äôt know what they were. If you haven‚Äôt read it, give it a try. It‚Äôs magical. I listened to the audiobook while on my daily walks, and Ethan Hawke does a fabulous job of narrating.
Ready for a drive, perhaps. I was thinking like a duffer, and had teed.

Flew through this puzzle in less than half average time. Hope tomorrow makes up for it. I look so forward to Friday and Saturday and always feel a little let down if they feel like Tuesday or Wednesday.

That said, this puzzle was fun and beautifully constructed.

I got the word play for 5A immediately, but struggled with the actual answer. I tried ORCHESTRA (too long) and WIND BAND (crosses didn't work), then wasn't sure what other music genre had horns. Turns out I missed a few genres of music!  (Also, I was thinking "horns" as only French horns, rather than a synonym for instruments...)

This was one of those puzzles where I couldn't fill in the grid fast enough. Every answer came to me almost immediately, even the long ones. Am I brilliant? No, of course not. I credit deft cluing that slyly pointed me in the right direction. This was maybe my fastest Friday ever, which ordinarily would be kind of a bummer, because I look forward to the challenge, but today it was just a joy. Thanks for the fun.

Love the llamas in france picture, Deb! But we also need the Funky Chicken. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lCI63H1neY Strands was just right. Strands #187 ‚ÄúJust right‚Äù üü°üîµüîµüîµ üîµüîµüîµüîµ üîµ
35D:  bajo means short and alto, its opposite, means tall in Spanish.

On of those ones where I started with almost no fills and thought it was hopeless only to succeed fairly steadily. And reading the comments I guess that‚Äôs because it wasn‚Äôt super hard. I, too, love the word ephemeral, especially as it relates to spring wildflowers.
Daddy sang bass mama sang teno.

I have always loved words that suggest a mysterious impermanence. Evanescent is similar to ephemeral, but with shimmer. Ephemera has substance and can be touched, but has importance that is not meant to last. Libraries have collections of ephemera, but evanescence is like the aurora or mirages and cannot be captured. 

Evanescence is enchanting, but someone else's scrapbook of ephemera can conjure glimpses of experience that disappear even before they are seen.

On to the Saturday puzzle.

The article I received in my email about the crosswords getting easier confirmed my suspicions. I was rather bummed to read that because of software use the puzzles are not as challenging. Is there a way to bring back the challenge using software? Many Fridays and Saturday puzzles go awfully quick. Granted there are a few that are a challenge but I wish there were more.

Deeebbbb! (Shake fist) I thought I was done for the week, last meeting done and puzzle complete, but now of course I have to tackle the quintuple stack puzzle you posted. 

Supper will have to wait.
I had YAP instead of YIP. A promise still made sense to me. I promise.
‚ÄúBajo‚Äù is Spanish for short or low. ‚ÄúAlto‚Äù is the opposite. It means tall or high.
Fun puzzle today, but that quintuple stack from 2012 has some pretty dodgy words crossing it. Glad I wasn‚Äôt in the game that day!
Bajo is short in Spanish, and alto is tall in Spanish. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs the opposite of bajo, not singing pitches

A great example of what can be so satisfying about a classic Friday offering. More smart than clever, sturdy, a few laughs you think you might be sharing with the author and the casual becoming elegant.
NE corner was just too hard for me. I had to give up and read Deb‚Äôs column üòí

35D - Bajo = LOW, Alto = HIGH as in altitude
Not a musical reference
Soda bread isn't leavened with sour milk. I mean, it's right there in the name: "SODA bread". It's leavened with baking soda.

I just have to complain about the cross YIP/IPROMISE. I had an A rather than an I, which is a perfectly reasonable choice considering entries have started with articles before,  Thanks to my wife for the hint.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
One of my least favorite crosswords I‚Äôve done. 63A truly irritated me because the answer is not correct. The answer is the goddess of FERTILITY not CHILDBIRTH.

I just finished the Friday Puzzle.  Today is Saturday, I completed the last Sunday puzzle that I had been working all week. It was exhausting. The Mon, Tues, Wed, Thurs. puzzles were great and I had fun completing them. Friday puzzle was harder of course.  It's supposed to be.  I'll tackle the Sat. puzzle after I do the other word games.  I'm all crossword puzzled out right now.  As far a the Friday puzzle, I agree with some of the comments regarding a few of the clues being a little off/confused me.  But I know there are different meanings and references, so always give the constructer a pass unless it's just egregious.  Friday puzzle was doable. I liked the long crosses and got them all. Now on to get my üêù, üåà, WORDLE, and Strand on.

Cheers from Texas y'all, Welcome to fall and a happy weekend!

I can‚Äôt believe I finished a Friday on my own when I was so I was sure I would have to look up for help. I was definitely on the same wavelength as the creator and with lots of pauses it was a very chewy solve. I loved the Crayola clue and the use of the Spanish ALTO. Great work!

@John H. 

I thought the middle stack was pretty easy. That's one of the things about the big stacks--they tend to either be easy or impossible (at least for me!).

PORTRAIT came easily and PAINTERS was too long; the A in ALTO gave me ARTISTS. 39A and 40A crossed with very helpful down words, so they weren't too much slower.

Up in the top third, I though SKA BANDS and PEACE DEAL (not PACT) were fairly tricky.

@Bill in Yokohama 

Thanks for the link.  First time I've tried a New Yorker puzzle.  It was pretty simple.

I never heard of ackee, interesting.

____________________

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade

@JulesDisch 

And that's all there is to that.  Not necessary to get into vocal ranges.  

If it weren't for the fact that I stopped to make myself a bowl of ice cream before reading the column, I'd have scooped you on this one.  (See what I did?)

Second week in a row that the 'splainer needed 'splaining.
Bajo is spanish for short, alto is spanish for tall.

@Barry Ancona 
You got mine, 10 hours later above.

I don't see the "hate" from posters* being any different lately.

But I will offer a sincere golf clap to Adrian.

*Insufficient?
@Frank I actually wrote EffEMERAL, but it didn‚Äôt last long.

@Paul Turner 

That's the nature of ephemera‚Äîhere one minute, gone the next.

                      ‚òÅÔ∏è

@Grant
I knew about pangolins because , tragically, they are the most trafficked species. Just like the misguided people who use rhino horn in their folk medicine, they are poached because their scales are made of keratin.

@Jim Yeah, that soda bread clue was a little off. Soda bread, as the name suggests, is leavened with baking soda. It might contain sour milk as an ingredient, and that sour milk interacts with the soda to create rise, but the sour milk alone will not do it.

@Mark 

Methinks you don't understand the wordplay in 53D, or else you wouldn't think it's a bit of a stretch.

CDs are played in a CD drive, so if something is ON CD, it's ready for a drive; i.e., to go into a drive.

Maybe you did realize this and still didn't like the clue.  But that's just a personal opinion.

Has the crossword gotten easier?
By Christina Iverson

Welcome to Easy Mode! Today I‚Äôll be answering a question from Richard Hoyt of Geneva, N.Y., who writes: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing the Saturday crosswords from the archives. They are significantly more difficult than more recent Saturday crosswords. They‚Äôre full of obscure references (Drift Prairie), questionable terms (sleep sofa), rarely heard words (tenurable) (Aug. 16, 2008). When and why did they get easier?‚Äù

I‚Äôll be answering this question in two parts. One big reason that crosswords have gotten easier over the years is that most crosswords now are created with the assistance of software, which allows for a higher standard of cleanliness in the grid.

End of part one.

Although the slang "T MEN" is somewhat old-fashioned, it's still very much in use, and thus not really Crosswordese: two acquaintances whom I have met at the gym I work out at, and who work for the Treasury--one of whom is in his early thirties, and rather hip--have both described themselves as "T-men."

TIL that I have been mistaken about the color "puce."
I connect it with the phrase "Pomegranate and Puce," the High School team colors of Frostbite Falls, MN, as stated by noted ALUM Bullwinkle J. Moose. Somehow I always imagined a fulvous yellow, as so many schools have Crimson and Gold (or the like) as colors. Now I realize that Frostbite Falls is, in fact, a rather monochrome place.

Although I know that "puce" is the French word for flea, I never connected it with the color. There is a small community NW of Windsor, ON, along the south shore of Lake St. Clair, which is named Puce (the dinner party I was at last night is not far from it). My guess is that the original settlers were harassed by sand-flies, hence the name. My partner informs my that until a few decades ago it was predominantly francophone. But by what demonym should we call the inhabitants--Pucites? Putians? Pukers?

I found this pretty easy for a Friday, with the exception of the SW corner where ON CD as the answer to "ready for a drive" really threw me.  So misleading -- and not in a good way.  Let me ask:  the music was on an LP or on an IPod and you transferred it to a CD so that it would now be "ready" to pop into your car's CD player?  You get your songs "ready for a drive". do you?  I quite disliked this clue.

But the names were minimal, I'm happy to say, and I actually knew KATHY and IRENE.  And DIANA, too, but not in that context.  I know her as the Goddess of the Hunt but not as the Goddess of Childbirth.  How interesting.  Take note, JD Vance:  We women don't have to abandon our careers to stay home and have babies and cater to our men; we can have it all.  Remember -- hunting was a major career at one time in history.  So DIANA really did it all!

Nice clues for BUGLE; ALIAS; DANCE and ANT.  Remind me never to have a piece of SODA BREAD (36D) as long as I live.
TIL that female llamas have something in common with female humans I asked out in high school!

This solve was punctuated by moments ‚Äì Perception Pings, let‚Äôs say ‚Äì where you are seriously flummoxed by a clue, with your forehead wrinkled, then through crosses the answer comes, and just for a precious tiny moment, you remain baffled, and then, with an inner laugh, comes the explosive ping, when the rightness of the answer hits you. 

And suddenly it feels like you‚Äôre at a lit party as you‚Äôre thinking ‚ÄúHah!  Cool!  Clever!‚Äù and such.   Just for a moment, though. Then you move on, leave it behind, but your mood has raised a notch.

This happened again and again today, for instance, with [Something made just for show?] for SET, [Competitions with many missions] for SPACE RACE, and [Ready for a drive, perhaps?] for ON CD.

I leave a puzzle like this awed and grateful, surging into the day ahead.

That surge today was buttressed by beauty in the box.  That center stack with not only gorgeous answers but ringing with freshness, with the middle answer used only once before in a Times puzzle, sandwiched by two debut answers.  Plus, the lovely longs of SODA BREAD, RAW NERVES, UMPTEENTH, and TEEN VOGUE.  And the loveliest of all: EPHEMERAL.

All this goodness just from letters in a box ‚Äì amazing!  You hit it just right today Adrian.  Thank you so much for this ‚Äì this was a wow!

Funny, I just last night I used the word "ephemeral": around 9:30pm, as my partner and I were driving home from a lovely pool-side dinner party (where we were served delicious empanadas, beef sliders, and soda bread), I was on my phone, on the NYT crossword app: "So what are you reading on your phone?" "I'm doing one last late night check on the Wordplay comments. You know, one of the things I like about it is that it really is ephemeral--all those topics, all those disputes which so engrossed us today, by tomorrow are completely forgotten, replaced by new ones." https://tinyurl.com/34rpzjnx See you tomorrow.

@JB
I‚Äôm with you. I often leave the puzzle open on my iPad and go off to tend to something or other and come back to it, as you say, with fresh eyes. I leave the clock running of course, so my times are not accurate. We all have different personal rules, don‚Äôt we?

@Bonnie Ann On further consideration, I'm also more inclined to let it pass, since the baking soda does need something acidic to activate, and sour milk can be that acidic thing. But it could also be buttermilk or even vinegar. So you do need something sour, but the soda is what's really doing the work of leavening.
@Marlys   In NYC, Spanish speakers often refer to Washington Heights/Inwood as Alto Manhattan and the Lower East Side as Bajo Manhattan.
